docs.snippet: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 8 People with United States dollars have become more popular than usual in this little Central American capital. Shops compete with banks in the currency exchange business as Costa Rica struggles to emerge from one of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 8 People with United States dollars have become more popular than usual in this little Central American capital. Shops compete with banks in the currency exchange business as Costa Rica struggles to emerge from one of the most serious financial crises of her history.
docs.abstract: Financial crisis over internatl payments and domestic deficits discussed; Govt optimistic that partial currency devaluation, new taxes and reopening of internatl credit lines have eased situation; nation's difficulty in trying to meet Alliance for Progress goal of 2.5% annual growth rate noted

headline.main: Financial Woes Beset Costa Rica Despite Reforms and New Taxes

byline.original: By HENRY GINIGER Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The State Department announced today that it was recalling Wymberley Coerr, United States Ambassador to Ecuador, following Ecuadorian charges that he had issued "public, open criticism" of President Otto Arosemena Gomez.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The State Department announced today that it was recalling Wymberley Coerr, United States Ambassador to Ecuador, following Ecuadorian charges that he had issued "public, open criticism" of President Otto Arosemena Gomez.
docs.abstract: State Dept repts it is recalling Amb to Ecuador Coerr following Ecuadorian charges he insulted Pres Arosemena in s on Alliance for Progress; US will not reciprocate even though it regards charges as unjustified

headline.main: U.S. Withdrawing Ambassador At the Request of Ecuadorians; He Is Accused of Criticizing President, but Washington Calls Charge Unjustified

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Contemporary England or Scandinavia might well take a long southwesterly look at Uruguay while murmuring: "There but for the grace of God go I." For Uruguay is the welfare state gone wild, and this fact, at last acknowledged by...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Contemporary England or Scandinavia might well take a long southwesterly look at Uruguay while murmuring: "There but for the grace of God go I." For Uruguay is the welfare state gone wild, and this fact, at last acknowledged by the Government, brought about today's political crisis and the declaration of a state of emergency.

headline.main: Foreign Affairs: Where but for the Grace of God
